    How to use this package

    Mauricio Vargas

    2020-01-03

    basic-usage.Rmd

    Basic trade example (Economy)

    Package data

    I’ll use this demo dataset to illustrate the essential usage of the functions within this package.

    library(binet)

trade_1962
    ## # A tibble: 44,435 x 3
## # Groups:   reporter_iso [158]
##    country product   value
##    <chr>   <chr>     <dbl>
##  1 afg     0106        621
##  2 afg     0405       3380
##  3 afg     0407      60807
##  4 afg     0501    1466840
##  5 afg     0504    1466840
##  6 afg     0703      85258
##  7 afg     0712       9057
##  8 afg     0714     164694
##  9 afg     0801    8482381
## 10 afg     0802    8437060
## # … with 44,425 more rows

    Balassa Index (or Revealed comparative Advantage, RCA)

    You can obtain Balassa Index with balassa_index().

    bi <- balassa_index(
  d = trade_1962,
  x = "country",
  y = "product",
  v = "value"
)

bi
    ## # A tibble: 44,435 x 3
##    country product value
##    <chr>   <chr>   <dbl>
##  1 afg     0106        0
##  2 afg     0405        0
##  3 afg     0407        0
##  4 afg     0501        1
##  5 afg     0504        1
##  6 afg     0703        0
##  7 afg     0712        0
##  8 afg     0714        1
##  9 afg     0801        1
## 10 afg     0802        1
## # … with 44,425 more rows

    You can also obtain it in matrix version.

    bi_m <- balassa_index(
  d = trade_1962,
  x = "country",
  y = "product",
  v = "value",
  tbl = F
)

# 5x5 preview
bi_m[1:5,1:5]
    ## 5 x 5 sparse Matrix of class "dgCMatrix"
##     0101 0102 0103 0104 0105
## afg    .    .    .    .    .
## ago    .    .    .    .    .
## alb    .    .    .    .    .
## and    .    .    .    .    .
## ant    .    .    .    .    .

    Another possibility is to obtain Balassa Index as a matrix or tibble without discretization.

    bi_dec <- balassa_index(
  d = trade_1962,
  x = "country",
  y = "product",
  v = "value",
  discrete = F
)

bi_dec
    ## # A tibble: 44,435 x 3
##    country product    value
##    <chr>   <chr>      <dbl>
##  1 afg     0106     0.0412 
##  2 afg     0405     0.00944
##  3 afg     0407     0.275  
##  4 afg     0501    14.4    
##  5 afg     0504    20.7    
##  6 afg     0703     0.271  
##  7 afg     0712     0.220  
##  8 afg     0714     3.18   
##  9 afg     0801    34.4    
## 10 afg     0802    48.0    
## # … with 44,425 more rows
    bi_dec_m <- balassa_index(
  d = trade_1962,
  x = "country",
  y = "product",
  v = "value",
  tbl = F,
  discrete = F
)

# 5x5 preview
bi_dec_m[1:5,1:5]
    ## 5 x 5 sparse Matrix of class "dgCMatrix"
##     0101       0102 0103 0104 0105
## afg    . .             .    .    .
## ago    . 0.01826164    .    .    .
## alb    . .             .    .    .
## and    . .             .    .    .
## ant    . .             .    .    .

    Complexity Measures

    You can compute both Economic Complexity Index (ECI) and Product Complexity Index (PCI) by using complexity_measures(). The calculations methods are reflections, eigenvalues and fitness (default). See (Mariani et al. 2015) for the methodological details.

    com_ref <- complexity_measures(
  bi = bi,
  x = "country",
  y = "product",
  v = "value",
  method = "reflections"
)

com_ref$complexity_index_x
    ## # A tibble: 158 x 2
##    country value
##    <chr>   <dbl>
##  1 deu      2.23
##  2 spm      2.20
##  3 fro      2.04
##  4 che      2.03
##  5 swe      1.99
##  6 jpn      1.91
##  7 aut      1.86
##  8 fra      1.86
##  9 ddr      1.84
## 10 gbr      1.83
## # … with 148 more rows
    com_ref$complexity_index_y
    ## # A tibble: 991 x 2
##    product value
##    <chr>   <dbl>
##  1 7111     1.73
##  2 9112     1.57
##  3 8804     1.43
##  4 8208     1.40
##  5 9108     1.37
##  6 7107     1.34
##  7 4906     1.33
##  8 8468     1.32
##  9 3813     1.32
## 10 7221     1.31
## # … with 981 more rows
    com_eig <- complexity_measures(
  bi = bi,
  x = "country",
  y = "product",
  v = "value",
  method = "eigenvalues"
)

com_eig$complexity_index_x
    ## # A tibble: 158 x 2
##    country value

##  2 spm      2.20
##  3 fro      2.04
##  4 che      2.03
##  5 swe      1.99
##  6 jpn      1.91
##  7 aut      1.86
##  8 fra      1.86
##  9 ddr      1.84
## 10 gbr      1.83
## # … with 148 more rows
    com_eig$complexity_index_y
    ## # A tibble: 991 x 2
##    product value
##    <chr>   <dbl>
##  1 7111     1.73
##  2 9112     1.57
##  3 8804     1.43
##  4 8208     1.40
##  5 9108     1.37
##  6 7107     1.34
##  7 4906     1.33
##  8 8468     1.32

    com_fit <- complexity_measures(
  bi = bi,
  x = "country",
  y = "product",
  v = "value",
  method = "fitness"
)

    Proximity

    Proximity matrices are used to create both country-country and product-product networks. Using proximity() is straightforward.

    pro <- proximity(
  bi = bi,
  x = "country",
  y = "product",
  v = "value",
  d = com_fit$diversity,
  dx = "country",
  dv = "value",
  u = com_fit$ubiquity,
  uy = "product",
  uv = "value"
)

pro$proximity_x
    ## # A tibble: 10,432 x 3
##    from  to      value
##    <chr> <chr>   <dbl>
##  1 ago   afg   0.0962 
##  2 alb   afg   0.219  
##  3 arg   afg   0.120  
##  4 aus   afg   0.111  
##  5 aut   afg   0.00690
##  6 bdi   afg   0.0714 
##  7 bel   afg   0.00938
##  8 ben   afg   0.107  
##  9 bfa   afg   0.0816 
## 10 bgr   afg   0.0945 
## # … with 10,422 more rows
    pro$proximity_y
    ## # A tibble: 417,822 x 3
##    from  to    value
##    <chr> <chr> <dbl>
##  1 0102  0101  0.346
##  2 0103  0101  0.263
##  3 0104  0101  0.421
##  4 0106  0101  0.2  
##  5 0201  0101  0.381
##  6 0203  0101  0.474
##  7 0204  0101  0.158
##  8 0205  0101  0.368
##  9 0206  0101  0.316
## 10 0207  0101  0.368
## # … with 417,812 more rows

    Networks

    The proximity_networks() function is designed to use igraph for the internal computations and also to pass proximity-based networks to igraph, ggraph or export to Cytoscape by saving the output as csv/tsv.

    net <- projections(
  px = pro$proximity_x,
  py = pro$proximity_y,
  tol = 0.1,
  f = "from",
  t = "to",
  v = "value"
)

net$network_x
    ## # A tibble: 157 x 3
##    from  to     value
##    <chr> <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 irn   afg   -0.5  
##  2 npl   afg   -0.214
##  3 syr   afg   -0.357
##  4 ago   ben   -0.339
##  5 ago   per   -0.358
##  6 ago   sen   -0.308
##  7 irn   alb   -0.375
##  8 sur   and   -0.130
##  9 bhr   ant   -0.312
## 10 sur   ant   -0.304
## # … with 147 more rows
    net$network_y
    ## # A tibble: 990 x 3
##    from  to     value
##    <chr> <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 9614  0101  -0.579
##  2 0102  0104  -0.423
##  3 0102  0201  -0.5  
##  4 0103  0505  -0.647
##  5 1102  0105  -0.417
##  6 4803  0105  -0.417
##  7 0106  1302  -0.514
##  8 0201  0208  -0.619
##  9 0201  0210  -0.524
## 10 0201  0409  -0.571
## # … with 980 more rows

    Just two basic examples with ggraph.

    library(igraph)
library(ggraph)
library(magrittr)

set.seed(200100)

net$network_x %>%
  graph_from_data_frame(directed = F) %>%
  ggraph(layout = "kk") +
  geom_edge_link(aes(edge_alpha = value, edge_width = value),
                 edge_colour = "#a8a8a8") +
  geom_node_point(color = "darkslategray4", size = 8) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = name), vjust = 2.2) +
  ggtitle("The Country Space") +
  theme_void()

    net$network_y %>%
  graph_from_data_frame(directed = F) %>%
  ggraph(layout = "kk") +
  geom_edge_link(aes(edge_alpha = value, edge_width = value),
                 edge_colour = "#a8a8a8") +
  geom_node_point(color = "darkslategray4", size = 4) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = name), vjust = 2.2) +
  ggtitle("The Product Space") +
  theme_void()

    References

    Mariani, Manuel, Alexandre Vidmer, Matsúš Medo, and Yi-Cheng Zhang. 2015. “Measuring Economic Complexity of Countries and Products: Which Metric to Use?” The European Physical Journal B 88 (11). Springer: 293. https://doi.org/10.1140/epjb/e2015-60298-7.
